columns.text: In this problem, we will determine whether the two companies should invest in the given market based on the expected returns as well as their respective betas.

In evaluating whether a company should invest in something, it is usually a good practice to compare the net present value. The net present value measures the investment's assets minus its liabilities and costs. A positive net present value indicates that the investment is profitable while a negative net present value means that the investment will lose value. 

In this case, however, both companies have the same net present values at the same discount rates. This means that we cannot use the net present value as the basis.

What we can use for this is the company's beta. The beta of a company is a numerical value assigned to the company's volatility in the market. This indicates how much the price of the company's stock fluctuates with respect to the market. 

A beta that is higher than 1 means that the movement of the company's stock price is greater than that of the market meaning it has higher highs and lower lows. 

A beta that is lower than 1 indicates that the movement of the market is greater than the movement of the stock price.

With this, we know that a more volatile stock can earn more but it can also lose more. Therefore, when comparing the two companies, only Superior should invest since it has a lower beta. This means that the value of the company has a lower likelihood to dip compared to that of Dow which means that investing in this will be more profitable and more sustainable for Superior.

Numerically, we can solve for this by taking the beta of the company and multiplying it by the expected risk premium. The product will then be added to the risk-free rate. This will give us the expected rate. 

For Dow:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected rate}&=(1.25 \times 0.08)+0.12\\[15 pt]
&=0.22\\[15 pt]
&=22\%
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see here, the expected rate that we get for Dow is the same rate that nets the negative net present value. 

For Superior:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected rate}&=(0.75 \times 0.08)+0.12\\[15 pt]
&=0.18\\[15 pt]
&=18\%
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see, the expected rate for Dow is the rate that gives a positive net present value, therefore, only Dow should invest in the project.

In conclusion, when comparing two investments that have the same net present value, it is always useful to know how volatile the stock price of the companies are and from there, a decision can be made more easily.
